slides.title: Introduction to Integration
slides.ocrText: Introduction to Integration

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives • Identify common Integration Mechanisms

used in InsuranceSuite

• Describe integration mechanisms commonly
used by technical consultants

• List resources available to technical
consultants

slides.title: i InsuranceSuite integration mechanisms: Overview [Fj
slides.originalNotes:
Insurance Suite integration mechanisms: Overview
Java Platform, Enterprise Edition (Java EE) The Application Server implements Java EE technology which defines the standard for developing multitier enterprise applications. The Java EE platform simplifies enterprise applications by basing them on standardized, modular components, by providing a complete set of services to those components, and by handling many details of application behavior automatically, without complex programming.

 In the next section we will identify five common integration mechanisms used in Guidewire InsuranceSuite:
Batch processes
Database tables
Web Services
Messaging, and
Plugins — Startable and Pre-defined.

slides.title: i Integration mechanism: Batch processes
slides.originalNotes:
Integration mechanism: Batch processes
A batch process completes background work that must be done on a periodic basis without user input. In this regard, a batch process is not triggered typically by a specific business event.
slides.notes:
Integration mechanism: Batch processes
A batch process completes background work that must be done on a periodic basis without user input. In this regard, a batch process is not triggered typically by a specific business event.

slides.title: i Integration Mechanism: Integration tables
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Mechanism: Integration tables
Often, an integration point needs to write information that is static, queryable, processable and reprocessable. Integration points based on writin information initially to a file can be unstable — the file could easily be deleted and there may not be an easy way to retrieve or recreate it- Integration points that initially write information to a stand- alone database table are more stable. The rows in the database cannot easily be deleted. They provide a static snapshot of the data at a given point in time. The information can be queried, flagged as processed, and potentially reprocessed ifsomething goes wrong.
Common data access technologies used for Integration tables:
 JDBC -JDBC is an API for the Java programming language that defines how a client may access a database. It provides methods for querying updating data in a database. JDBC is oriented towards relational databases. A JDBC-to- ODBC bridge enables connections to any ODBC-accessible data source in the JVM host environment
Spring — The Spring Framework is an open source application framework for the Java platform. Althrough the Spring Framework does not impose any specific programming model, it has become popular in the Java community as an alternative to replacement for, or even addition to the JavaBean model.
Hibernate — Hibernate is an object-relational mapping (ORM) library for the Java language, providing a framework for mapping an object-oriented domain model to a traditional relational database. Hibernates primary feature is mapping from Java classes to database tables (and from Java data types to SQL data types).

Hibernates primary feature is mapping from Java classes to database tables (and from Java data types to SQL data types).

slides.title: i Integration Tables for file-based exchange
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Tables for file-based exchange
When data must be written out to a static repository, the most common technique is to use an integration table. The table sits in a separate database. Either Guidewire or an external system writes information to the table. Periodically, some sort of tool, such as a batch process, processes the rows in the table. For example, a batch process could write all unprocessed rows in the table into a file, change the status of the unprocessed rows to processed, and then make the file available to the consuming system. This practice is recommended under Guidewire Best Practices for file-based exchange as well.

Integration tables are not used just to generate files. They can also be used for reporting, data warehouses, or any other requirement in which one must have a snapshot of the state of the application at a specific point in time. For example, an integration point could contain information about invoices overdue or claims filed. This information could then be copied into a data warehouse.

slides.title: i Integration Mechanism: Web services
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Mechanism: Web services
RESTful Web Services - REST stands for
Representational State Transfer. REST is an architectural style not a protocol.

Advantages of RESTful
Web Services:
• Fast-RESTful Web Services are fast because there is no strict specification like SOAP. It consumes less bandwidth and resources.
Language and Platform independent — RESTful web services can be written in any programming language and executed in any platform-
• Can use SOAP —
RESTful web services can use SOAP web services as the implementation. Permits different data format — RESTful web service permits different data format such as Plain Text, HTML, XML and JSON.

SOAP Web Services —
SOAP stands for Simple Object Access Protocol. It is a XML-based protocol for accessing web services. SOAP is a W3C
recommendation for communication between two applications. It is platform independent and language independent. By using SOAP, you will be able to interact with other programming language appIications .

Advantages of Soap Web Services:
WS Security – SOAP defines its own security known as WS Security.
Language and Platform independent — SOAP web services can be written in any programming language and executed in any platform.
Disadvantages of Soap
Web Services:
Slow - SOAP uses XML format that must be parsed to be read. It defines many standards that must be followed while developing the SOAP applications. So it is slow and consumes more bandwidth and resource.
WSDL dependent — SOAP uses WSDL and the ways to discover the service are not widely diffused (UDDI).
slides.notes:

SOAP Web Services —
SOAP stands for Simple Object Access Protocol. It is a XML-based protocol for accessing web services. SOAP is a W3C
recommendation for communication between two applications. It is platform independent and language independent. By using SOAP, you will be able to interact with other programming language appIications .

Advantages of Soap Web Services:
WS Security – SOAP defines its own security known as WS Security.
Language and Platform independent — SOAP web services can be written in any programming language and executed in any platform.
Disadvantages of Soap
Web Services:
Slow - SOAP uses XML format that must be parsed to be read. It defines many standards that must be followed while developing the SOAP applications. So it is slow and consumes more bandwidth and resource.
WSDL dependent — SOAP uses WSDL and the ways to discover the service are not widely diffused (UDDI).

slides.title: i Integration Mechanism: Messaging
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Mechanism: Messaging
Messaging involves the exchange of data between two systems that consists of messages. Each message describes events, requests, and/or replies. The exchange of information in messaging is typically asynchronous. The system that creates the message does not necessarily send the message immediately after it has been created. The system that receives the message does not necessarily process the message immediately after it is received.

Sun Microsystem's Java Message Service (JMS) and IBM's MQSeries are examples of technologies that provide messaging interfaces and service.
slides.notes:
Integration Mechanism: Messaging
Messaging involves the exchange of data between two systems that consists of messages. Each message describes events, requests, and/or replies. The exchange of information in messaging is typically asynchronous. The system that creates the message does not necessarily send the message immediately after it has been created. The system that receives the message does not necessarily process the message immediately after it is received.

Sun Microsystem's Java Message Service (JMS) and IBM's MQSeries are examples of technologies that provide messaging interfaces and service.
slides.ocrText:
i Integration Mechanism: Messaging Gi

Message Message Queue
GY —_&

Guidewire External
Application System

* One system sends a message to another system, which is placed in a queue, and
at a later point in time, the other system processes the message

* Typically, the target system provides an asynchronous, unequivocal acknowledgement when it
receives or processes the message

* Common messaging technologies:
« JMS
« MQSeries

slides.title: i Messaging in InsuranceSuite: An example
slides.originalNotes:
Messaging in Insurance Suite: An example
Insurance Suite supports asynchronous messaging with an event-based model that captures events in Insurance Suite applications and notifies subscribed systems of those events. For example, when a check is successfully created in ClaimCenter, Insurance Suite may send a request to a check printing system to issue a check for given claim. The Insurance Suite messaging framework uses a subscription model to guarantee at-least-once delivery of all messages by requiring an unequivocal acknowledgement from each target system to which a message was delivered- In the slide example, the Check Printing System will reply with a check number. Not all Guidewire messaging interactions will be asynchronous from the perspective of the target systems, but this is a common approach. Successful messaging to and from Insurance Suite makes use of:
Event Fired rules
Destinations Messaging plugins (These plugins have behaviors that are somewhat different than predefined plugins.)
XML or JSON

Examples of Insurance Suite applications using
Messaging:
PolicyCenter — Send billing instruction to BillingCenter for a new policy created in PolicyCenter
BillingCenter — Send notice of unpaid premium to a collection agency
ClaimCenter — Send request to check printing system to issue a check for given claim

slides.title: i Integration Mechanism: Startable plugins
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Mechanism: Star-table plugins
You can register custom code that runs at server startup in the form of a startable plugin implementation. You can use a startable plugin as a daemon, such as listenerto a JMS queue. You can use a startable plugin for periodic batch processing, such as deleting expired files from a file system folder. You can use a startable plugin as an initializer, such as loading configuration data into the application database.

You can start and stop startable plugins as circumstances require. You can't start or stop standard types of plugins. Instead, code in a standard Guidewire plugin executes only when other code invokes its methods.
slides.notes:

You can use a startable plugin as an initializer, such as loading configuration data into the application database.

You can start and stop startable plugins as circumstances require. You can't start or stop standard types of plugins. Instead, code in a standard Guidewire plugin executes only when other code invokes its methods.

slides.title: i Integration Mechanism: Predefined plugins
slides.originalNotes:
Integration Mechanism: Predefined plugins
Some predefined plugins must interact with external systems, such as an authentication plugin or a geocoding plugin. Other plugins are not required to interact with external systems. For example, number generator plugins generate unique numbers following specific patterns for primary entities- These plugins are not required to interact with external systems, and often they execute logic that is stored entirely within Guidewire.

In Guidewire, there are three functionally different types of plugins: messaging plugins, startable plugins, and predefined (non-messaging, non-startable)-

Note, plugins can also be written in Java- If you implement a plugin interface in Java, there are two ways to deploy your code:
• Java plugin —A Java class. You must use an IDE other than Studio. If you write your plugin in Java, you must regularly regenerate the Java API libraries to compile against the latest libraries- You can use any Java IDE. You can choose to use the included IntelliJ IDEA with OSGi Editor for Java plugin development even if you do not choose to use OSGi. To deploy your compiled Java classes and any libraries, see Deploy Non-OSGi Java Classes and JARs in the Integration Guide-
• OSGi plugin —A Java class encapsulated in an OSGi bundle. You must use an IDE other than Studio. The OSGi framework is a Java module system and service platform that helps cleanly isolate code modules and any necessary Java libraries. To simplify OSGi configuration, InsuranceSuite includes an application called IntelliJ IDEA with OSGi Editor. To deploy your compiled Java classes and any libraries, see OSGi Plugin Deployment with IntelliJ IDEA with OSGi Editor in the Integration Guide.

slides.title: i Contrasting integration mechanisms
slides.originalNotes:
Contrasting integration mechanisms
The table above contrasts different integration mechanisms with respect toData Exchange Timing(synch, asynch, and scheduled) and Data Exchange Direction(outbound and inbound) The table does not describe absolute rules, and any implementation may use the mechanisms in ways that do not exactly adhere to the table.

The columns of the table separate the mechanisms into two general categories:
Outbound, which means the data exchange is initiated by Guidewire, and
Inbound, which means the data exchange is initiated by the external system.
Keep in mind that most integration points involve a two-way exchange of data, regardless of who initiates the exchange. For example, when authenticating a user, Guidewire initially sends information to the external system- Then, the external system replies with information on whether the user has been authenticated- So data typically flows in both directions. The critical point is which system initiated the exchange.

* Some predefined plugins do not typically interact with other systems. For example, ClaimCenteis claim number generator plugin and BillingCenteds commission calculation plugin typically execute logic entirely internal to Guidewire. When a plugin does interact with other systems, the data exchange is outbound.
** Batch processes can be initiated by the scheduler or by a web service call from an external system- So technically, they could be either outbound or inbound- In practice, most batch processes are initiated by the scheduler and are therefore outbound. In other cases, Guidewire application initiate a batch process from the internal API-
slides.notes:

When a plugin does interact with other systems, the data exchange is outbound.
** Batch processes can be initiated by the scheduler or by a web service call from an external system- So technically, they could be either outbound or inbound- In practice, most batch processes are initiated by the scheduler and are therefore outbound. In other cases, Guidewire application initiate a batch process from the internal API-

slides.title: i The training environment
slides.originalNotes:
The training environment
Guidewire recommends that all development work be done using the Dynamic Code Evolution Virtual Machine (DCEVM). With DCEVM, there are numerous situations where you can deploy new code simply by saving the code in Studio and reloading the changed class or compiling the class- Without DCEVM, you must often stop and restart the server to deploy your new code. If your classroom environment was set up as recommended by Guidewire, then DCEVM has been installed. For more information on DCEVM, refer to the Installation Guide.

The Guidewire applications used in this course (TrainingApp and ExternalApp) come with shortcuts that can be used to start and stop the application and start Studio- These shortcuts assume that the Guidewire applications are in the directory. If these applications are stored in a different directory in your environment, then you will need to modify the shortcuts to point to the correct directories, or start and stop applications manually through the command line interface. You'll also need to update the database-config.xml and logging-properties (or log4j2.xml) files.

You will often work in Guidewire Studio and deploy changes in a Debug 'Server’ process. You can stop and start the debug 'server’ process from Guidewire Studio.

Studio is the primary IDE used for integration development
Create and register predefined plugins
Create web service collections to consume external SOAP web services
Create Guidewire web services (REST/SOAP) for external systems to consume
Create messaging integrations
Create startable plugins
Create batch processes

i The training environment

• This course make the following assumptions:
* You are working in development mode
« EnablelnternalDebugTools parameter in config.xml has been set to true
« You are using the Dynamic Code Evolution Virtual Machine (DCEVM)
• All Guidewire applications are located in the C:\GW directory
• The training environment also provides the following resources:
* TrainingApp
« ExternalApp

slides.title: i TrainingApp for integration students
slides.originalNotes:
Training App for integration students
TrainingApp is a modified version of Contact Manager- It is not sold as a genuine Guidewire product- It is used exclusively by GuidewireEducation for teaching students about platform-level functionality.

TrainingApp contains examples and partially-built functionality for both configuration students and integration students- The legal case report integration point shown above is a fullyfunctional integration point that uses Guidewire messaging and web services to request a legal case report from an external syste process the reply when it is received, and display any reports received. The integration point interacts with ExternalApp (which is discussed on the next slide), so you must have ExternalApp running to see the end-to-end functionality.

To view the legal case report integration point:
Start ExternalApp (Navigate to and double-click the Start ExternalApp shortcut.)
In TrainingApp, navigate to an ABDoctor (such as Samantha Andrews).
On the Details screen’s Person Info card, click the Request Case Report button. (This disables theRequest Case Report button and displays the Report requested text)
You can view the consoles of both TrainingApp and ExternalApp to view the exchange on information between the two systems.

slides.title: i ExternalApp for integration students
slides.originalNotes:
ExternalApp for integration students
ExternalApp is a modified version of Contact Manager. However, the modifications in ExternalApp are significantly less than that of TrainingApp. Beyond the base application, it has just a small number of web services, batch processes, and logic to react to incoming requests. You do not need to have ExternalApp running at all times. If a TrainingApp example or course lab requires the application to be running, then explicit notes or instructions identify this.

slides.title: i Guidewire integration documentation
slides.originalNotes:
Guidewire integration documentation
Documentation is located in<application>/doc folder.

There are several sets of documentation that are specific to a given instance of a Guidewire application. Each set must be generated. This includes the following:
The Data Dictionary, which documents the entities and typelists in the Guidewire data model. It is generated using the gwb genDataDictionary command (which also generates the Security Dictionary). Once generated, it is located in ary\data.
The Security Dictionary, which documents the system permissions and roles for the application. It is generated using the gwb genDataDictionary command (which also generates the Data Dictionary). Once generated, it is located in ary\security.
The GosuDocs, which documents the Gosu type system- It is generated using the gwb gosudoc command. Once generated, it is located in oc.
The Guidewire Java API Javadocs, which documents the Java classes that represent Guidewire entities, typelists, and plugin interfaces. It is generated using the gwb genJavaApi command. Once generated, it is located in <application>/Javadoc.

The Security Dictionary, which documents the system permissions and roles for the application. It is generated using the gwb genDataDictionary command (which also generates the Data Dictionary). Once generated, it is located in ary\security.
The GosuDocs, which documents the Gosu type system- It is generated using the gwb gosudoc command. Once generated, it is located in oc.
The Guidewire Java API Javadocs, which documents the Java classes that represent Guidewire entities, typelists, and plugin interfaces. It is generated using the gwb genJavaApi command. Once generated, it is located in <application>/Javadoc.

slides.title: i Deploying integration resources
slides.originalNotes:
Deploying integration resources
The chart shown here is a good reference to note as to what action to take during development to deploy changes.
slides.notes:
Deploying integration resources
The chart shown here is a good reference to note as to what action to take during development to deploy changes.
slides.ocrText:
i Deploying integration resources Ga

Resource Name New
RESTART RESTART
RESTART RESTART
RESTART RESTART
ALT + SHIFT +L ALT + SHIFT +L
ALT + SHIFT +L / RELOAD ALT + SHIFT + L/ RELOAD
RESTART RELOAD
RESTART RELOAD

Gosu Enhancement RESTART RELOAD

* Inadevelopment environment, resources require different actions to be deployed
+ ALT + SHIFT + L: reloads PCF and displaykey changes without restarting the Server

+ RELOAD: In Studio, Run> Reload Changed Classes

+ Deploying Gosu changes in a local development environment only works if DCEVM is installed on your
development machine

* Restarting the server always deploys all changed resources

questionData.question: Information exchange between systems that use the Internet for direct
questionData.answer: •~ ~ application-to-application interactions are known as: ? A) Messaging B) Batch Processes C) Web Services The correct answer is C) Web Services. SS eee ene ee soe Sse

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
Information exchange between systems that use the Internet for direct
•~ ~ application-to-application interactions are known as:
? A) Messaging
B) Batch Processes
C) Web Services
The correct answer is C) Web Services.

Question

typical “timing” (synchronous, asynchronous, or scheduled) and initial
,’ direction (outbound or inbound):

Predefined plugins
Web services
Messaging
Startable plugins
moom>

questionData.question: For each of the InsuranceSuite integration mechanisms, identify its
questionData.answer: Typical "timing" (synchronous, asynchronous, or scheduled) and initial direction (outbound or inbound): Predefined plugins — Synchronous and outbound Web services — Synchronous and inbound Messaging — Asynchronous and outbound Startable plugins — Asynchronous and inbound SS eee ene ee soe Sse Batch processes — Scheduled and outbound

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
For each of the InsuranceSuite integration mechanisms, identify its
typical "timing" (synchronous, asynchronous, or scheduled) and initial
direction (outbound or inbound):
Predefined plugins — Synchronous and outbound
Web services — Synchronous and inbound
Messaging — Asynchronous and outbound
Startable plugins — Asynchronous and inbound
